review.title: Structured Group Sparsity: A Novel Indoor WLAN Localization, Outlier Detection, and Radio Map Interpolation Scheme
review.abstract: This paper introduces novel schemes for indoor localization, outlier detection, and radio map interpolation using Wireless Local Area Networks (WLANs). The localization method consists of a novel multicomponent optimization technique that minimizes the squared $\ell_{2}$-norm of the residuals between the radio map and the online Received Signal Strength (RSS) measurements, the $\ell_{1}$-norm of the user's location vector, and weighted $\ell_{2}$-norms of layered groups of Reference Points (RPs). RPs are grouped using a new criterion based on the similarity between the so-called Access Point (AP) coverage vectors. In addition, since AP readings are prone to containing inordinate readings, called outliers, an augmented optimization problem is proposed to detect the outliers and localize the user with cleaned online measurements. Moreover, a novel scheme to record fingerprints from a smaller number of RPs and estimate the radio map at RPs without recorded fingerprints is developed using sparse recovery techniques. All localization schemes are tested on RSS fingerprints collected from a real environment. The overall scheme has comparable complexity with competing approaches, while it performs with high accuracy under a small number of APs and finer granularity of RPs.

sections.heading: A. Related Work
sections.text: The state-of-the-art localization approaches are divided into three broad categories, based mainly on their fine localization methods: 1) probabilistic approaches that determine the user's location based on statistical methods such as Kernel Density Estimation (KDE) [18], Conditional Random Fields (CRF) [31], KL divergence [32], Dynamic Hybrid Projection (DHP) [29]; 2) pattern recognition schemes such as Support-Vector Machines (SVM) [37], [38]; and 3) deterministic methods based on distance measurement between online measurements and radio map finger printing. Deterministic approaches are divided into Nearest Neighbor (NN) [42], Geometric Localization [33] - [35], and Compressive Sensor Location (CS) methods that determine the user's location.

sections.heading: B. Group Sparsity-Based Localization
sections.text: The main idea of the proposed localization scheme is to efficiently combine rough and fine localization in a single step. Thus, localization is accomplished by solving an optimization problem that combines the following objectives: • Minimizing the square '2 norm of residuals between the radio map and online measurements. • Restoring a sparse user position vector by minimizing the' 1 norm of the total user position vector. • Participating all RPs in the location estimation by taking into account the RP groups and their respective weights found in the first step (layered clustering). This is the group parity component and is expressed as the summation of the "2 standards of the groups of the RPs." This component shrinks the non-zero elements of the position vectors into a single group.

sections.heading: D. AP Selection
sections.text: Because WLANs are designed to provide maximum network coverage over the entire area, the number of available APs in an area is much larger than the number required for positioning. In addition, not all APs are suitable for positioning as high-variance APs, leading to distorted estimates. This motivates us to include a number of APs in the localization that can efficiently represent the characteristics of the environment.In our work, we have considered two AP selection methods: • Strongest APs Selection: In this method, we look at the set of APs whose online measurements exceed a predefined threshold. The intuition behind this idea is that the strongest APs can provide the best characteristics of the area.

sections.heading: VIII. EXPERIMENTS AND DISCUSSION
sections.text: In this section, we present our experimental results, which confirm the advantages of the proposed approach; the experimental setup, evaluation criteria and results are then elaborated.

sections.heading: A. Fingerprinting Device
sections.text: A collection of fingerprints was recorded using a Samsung tablet (Galaxy Tab A) and a proprietary Android application that runs on Android Lollipop 5.0.2 and uses the inherent packet features of android.net.wifi. This package gives the freedom to set the reading interval of the network card (NIC) of the device to the desired values. To our knowledge, the device has a delay in updating the NIC card, and therefore the sampling intervals cannot be set to small values. We set the application to read the NIC once a second to get the updated RSS values. The device also records the Media Access Control (MAC) address of each AP along with its RSS size.

sections.heading: B. Fingerprinting Setup
sections.text: The fingerprints were collected on the second floor of the Applied Engineering Technology (AET) building with an area of 576 ft x 35 ft, and on the second floor of the Biotechnology Sciences and Engineering (BSE) building with an area of 114 ft x 347 ft, both at the University of Texas in San Antonio, comparable to those reported in [18], [22]. Fig. 4 shows the map of the second floor of the AET, where the green dots represent the fingerprint locations. metadata.abstractText: This paper introduces novel schemes for indoor localization, outlier detection, and radio map interpolation using Wireless Local Area Networks (WLANs). The localization method consists of a novel multicomponent optimization technique that minimizes the squared `2-norm of the residuals between the radio map and the online Received Signal Strength (RSS) measurements, the `1-norm of the user’s location vector, and weighted `2-norms of layered groups of Reference Points (RPs). RPs are grouped using a new criterion based on the similarity between the so-called Access Point (AP) coverage vectors. In addition, since AP readings are prone to containing inordinate readings, called outliers, an augmented optimization problem is proposed to detect the outliers and localize the user with cleaned online measurements. Moreover, a novel scheme to record fingerprints from a smaller number of RPs and estimate the radio map at RPs without recorded fingerprints is developed using sparse recovery techniques. All localization schemes are tested on RSS fingerprints collected from a real environment. The overall scheme has comparable complexity with competing approaches, while it performs with high accuracy under a small number of APs and finer granularity of RPs.
